newsitem.title: DENMARK: Danish neo-nazi radio to be closed down.
newsitem.headline: Danish neo-nazi radio to be closed down.

text.p: Local radio authorities in south Copenhagen are to close Denmark's neo-Nazi radio station because to broadcast excerpts from Hitler's "Mein Kampf", the Danish Ritzau news agency reported on Wednesday.
"In our opinion the radio station has been broadcasting despicable statements," a spokesman for the local radio authority told the agency.
Radio Oasis went on the air in late February after being grudgingly granted a licence under Denmark's liberal freedom of speech laws.

The spokesman said licence was granted on condition that the station did not incite racial hatred among listeners, but it had broadcast extracts from "Mein Kampf", a book outlining the Nazi philosophy of the superiority of the Aryan race over Jews.
Danish neo-Nazi leader Jonni Hansen told Reuters: "The passage of 'Mein Kampf' which caused offence was in book two where Hitler likens negros to monkeys."

He added: "I have not yet received any written notice of the closure from the local radio committee but I am sure we will. We are going to appeal against the closure. We plan to continue broadcasting."

Radio Oasis -- "an oasis in the media desert" according to Hansen -- broadcast from the headquarters of Denmark's National Socialist Movement in the blue-collar community of Greve, 20 km (12 miles) south of Copenhagen.
It used a 30-watt transmitter so its reception area was limited to Greve and the surrounding suburbs.
